intro: Margaritaria obovata, commonly known as the diamondleaf or oblongleaf mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on various host trees, primarily in the tropics and subtropics. It has small, leathery, oval-shaped leaves that are often covered in a waxy coating, which helps reduce water loss. The plant produces small, white or pale green flowers that are typically clustered together, followed by berries that are toxic to many animals. Its seeds are dispersed by birds that eat the berries, making it an important part of its ecosystem. Margaritaria obovata is also known for its ability to survive in shaded environments, which contributes to its success as a parasite.
